title-group.article-title: Using Canonical Commonality Analysis to Examine the Predictive Quality of Aging and Falls Efficacy on Balance Functioning in Older Adults

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Health Education and Behavior, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, USA
2Department of Health Promotion, Coastal Carolina University, Conway, SC, USA
3Department of Kinesiology, Recreation, and Sport Studies, Coastal Carolina University, Conway, SC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Michael Stellefson, Department of Health Education and Behavior, University of Florida, PO Box 118210, Gainesville, FL 32611, USA Email: mstellefson@ufl.edu

abstract.p: Purpose: The effects of important variables measuring the psychobiological aspects of falls among older adults were considered to determine their utility in predicting balance functioning among older adults. To partition the effects of aging and falls efficacy on balance and leg strength simultaneously, canonical commonality analysis (CCA) was used. Methods: CCA is a multivariate technique which decomposes squared semipartial correlation effect sizes into constituent, nonoverlapping segments that describe unique and common explanatory powers of predictor variables. Data from a study conducted to examine the psychobiological and aging influences on unintended falls among physically active older adults were analyzed. Findings: CCA showed balance confidence as measured by the Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale (ABC) and age to be noteworthy predictors of balance; yet, age was determined to be more important than balance confidence when predicting balance and leg strength (i.e., balance functioning) simultaneously. In addition, results suggest that data obtained from the ABC better predicted balance functioning among active older adults as compared to the Tinetti Falls Efficacy Scale (FES), a traditional measure used to assess the construct. Conclusion: The ABC stands as a viable alternative to consider when assessing falls efficacy among dynamic older adults. Future research would benefit from using CCA to understand how various psychobiological constructs predict fall-related outcomes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Unintended falls among older adults remain an area of great concern for public health professionals. Recent data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) indicate that in the United States, over one third of people over the age of 65 experience at least one unintended fall each year, and those who fall once are two to three times more likely to fall again (Bludau & Lipsitz, 1997; Hausdorff, Rios, & Edelber, 2001; Stevens & Sogolow, 2008; Tinetti, 2003). Although falls are not necessarily an inevitable part of aging (Stevens & Sogolow, 2008; Yannessa, 2008), past prevalence data suggests that fall frequency increases in each age strata for both men and women aged 65–74, 75–84, and 85+ (Stevens, Corso, Finkelstein, & Miller, 2006). Past research has also indicated that many older adults who have fallen (and even many that have not fallen) experience some type of psychological issue related to falls (Tinetti, Richman, & Powell, 1990; Walker & Howland, 1991). For those who have not actually fallen, the prospect of falling is sometimes quite challenging psychologically (Cumming, Salkeld, Thomas, & Szonyi, 2000).

It is well-established that muscle mass and muscle strength decline with advancing age (Larsson, Grimby, & Karlsson, 1979; Lindle et al., 1997; Young, Stokes, & Crowe, 1985) and these declines have been linked to reduced muscle function (Hyatt, Whitelaw, Bhat, Scott, & Maxwell, 1990) and increased risk of falls (Campbell, Borrie, & Spears, 1989). Therefore, aging and the interaction of psychological variables and physical function outcomes (e.g., measures of muscle strength) are important to investigate as precursors to fall-related susceptibility. Past research has indicated an interrelatedness of physiological and psychological variables that may contribute to unintended falls among older adult populations. In that sense, falls are caused by complex interactions among several intrinsic risk factors (Connell & Wolf, 1997; Kannus, Sievänen, Palvanen, Järvinen, & Parkkari, 2005; Tinetti, 2003).

There has been a great deal of published data regarding the development of various instruments to quantify intrinsic issues such as fear of falling. In a previous review, Jorstad, Hauer, Becker, & Lamb (2005) identified 18 multiitem measures and 8 single-item fall-related psychological instruments. Evidence suggests that there is not a single instrument that can currently serve as a “gold standard” when seeking to measure psychological issues related to falls (Moore & Ellis, 2008). Various instruments have demonstrated ceiling effects reflecting scores not measuring or estimating variance above a certain threshold, which may explain the lack of instrumental responsiveness to change in relatively nonfrail older adults (Talley, Wyman, & Gross, 2008; Tzu-Ting & Woan-Shyuan, 2009). Even so, the Tinetti Falls Efficacy Scale (FES) and the Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale (ABC) remain two of the most widely used instruments to measure falls efficacy (Moore & Ellis, 2008).

Importantly, before researchers can determine which issues most impact falls, and which instruments are best to use in fall-related research situations, it is important to characterize and quantify the underlying relationship between issues such as falls efficacy, balance confidence, and other fall-related constructs (Moore & Ellis, 2008). Unfortunately, little research has investigated such variables using alternative models designed to embrace the multivariate nature of falls among older adults. To evaluate the effects of simultaneously considering these multiple variables, it is useful to invoke alternative regression models to understand the effects of psychological measures and aging (i.e., independent variables) on outcomes related to physical functioning (i.e., dependent variables). This task is often difficult due to multicollinearity (i.e., correlations) among predictor variables which are often encountered by health program evaluators. While multicollinearity can cause analytical barriers, correlations among predictor variables should be accounted for, as they quite often honor an ecological reality (Zientek & Thompson, 2006) time honored in health promotion circles (McLeroy, Bibeau, Steckler, & Glanz, 1988).

An alternative data analysis technique known as commonality analysis (Mayeske et al., 1969; Mood, 1971; Newton & Spurrell, 1967) can decompose an R 2-type effect size into constituent, nonoverlapping parts that describe both unique and common explanatory powers of sets of predictor variables, in all their possible combinations (Thompson, 2006). A multivariate application of commonality analysis has been described as canonical commonality analysis (CCA; Frederick, 1999). This analysis provides information regarding the variance explained by measured predictor variables and the common contribution of multiple predictor variables in a CCA (Frederick, 1999). Given the complex nature of physiological functioning variables shown to predispose older adults to unintended fall-related injuries (Lipsitz, et al., 1994; Nazarko, 2006; Swift, 2007), a multivariate model allows for the simultaneous examination of multiple predictors and outcomes. Tatsuoka (1973) notes that, “any variable taken in isolation may affect the criterion differently from the way it will act in the company of other variables … [and] overlooks the fact that [the simultaneous nature of] multivariate analysis can throw light on how each one contributes to the relation” (p. 273). Therefore, a multivariate model of reality, in a multicausal world of multiple effects, acts as a better fitting analytic model which provides more reliable results (Tatsuoka, 1971).

In addition, CCA eliminates the need to discard variance which is usually required when converting intervally scaled independent variables into arbitrary predictor categories (Frederick, 1999; Henson, 2000). The end result of a CCA illuminates output for the reader (Lohnes & Cooley, 1978) and accurately depicts which measures (e.g., psychological vs. aging) are truly responsible for predicting variance in a dependent variate/function (e.g., simultaneous interaction of physiological factors contributing to balance functioning). Therefore, the purpose of this manuscript is to partition the effects of aging and falls efficacy on balance and leg strength simultaneously through the implementation of CCA. Important variables measuring the psychobiological aspects of falls among older adults will be considered.

sec.title: Fundamentals of CCA
sec.p: In the multivariate or canonical case, the unique contribution of a predictor is the squared semipartial correlation between the predictor and the criterion variate/function, after partialling out all other predictor variables in a regression model (Pedhazur, 1997). The common contributions of predictor variables represent explained variance shared among two or more predictor variables when regressed onto a criterion variate/function. Common contributions of predictors should not be confused with interaction effects in regression, which occur when adding a predictor to a model increases predictive ability of a variable which has already been entered. Moreover, a CCA determines “the variance explained that two or more predictor variables share that is useful in predicting relationships with the criterion variable set” (Capraro & Capraro, 2001, p. 17). Partitioning the unique and commonly shared variance helps determine the true predictive power of individual predictor variables and proves invaluable when determining parsimony in a multivariable model.

To conduct a three-variable CCA, seven distinct regression equations are necessary, where all possible combinations of predictor variables are entered into a multivariate model. The first three regressions are simple regressions entering each unique predictor, the next three consist of all possible combinations of two of the three predictors, and the last regression would enter all three predictors simultaneously. The R 2-type effect sizes produced from these regressions are imputed into the formula presented in Table 1 to determine unique and common components of shared variance predicting a dependent function/variate. Cooley and Lohnes (1976, p. 222) provide formulas for up to four predictor variables, and Seibold and McPhee (1979) provide tables for studies involving up to five predictors.

caption.p: Formulas for Determining Unique and Common Components of Shared Variance

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: A convenience sample of older adults participated in a study examining the psychobiological influences on unintended falls among older adults (Yannessa, Martel, & Newton, 2008). The sample was recruited through advertisements in local newspapers and postings at local hospitals and health/fitness centers in the southeastern United States. Participants completed various psychological and physical performance tests, as well as a thorough health history questionnaire that screened for musculoskeletal, metabolic, and pulmonary disorders. The health history also elicited information regarding physical activity habits, medications, and previous fall history. In order to participate in this study, participants had to be living at home and be at least 50 years of age. Individuals reporting or exhibiting signs or symptoms of unstable angina, orthostatic hypotension, systemic illness or fever, or poor coronary artery blood flow were excluded from participation.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: In an effort to be responsive to recent evidence in the falls literature (Lipsitz et al., 1994; Nazarko, 2006; Swift, 2007), the following four measures were used during data collection: the Berg Balance Test (BBT), (FES), (ABC), and the one-repetition maximum leg press (LGPRS).

The BBT is a commonly used clinical tool for assessing balance ability in older adults (Berg, Wood-Dauphinee, Williams, & Maki, 1992). Its administration involves 14 brief tasks such as a timed bipedal stance with participants’ eyes open and closed and a timed one leg stance. Measurements obtained with this test have demonstrated excellent interrater reliability and a tendency toward at least moderately strong concurrent validity (Berg et al., 1992).

The FES (Tinetti et al., 1990) assesses an older adult’s confidence in unintended fall avoidance while completing activities of daily living (ADL). The scale items assess confidence related to 10 relatively nonhazardous activities rated on a 10-point scale. Due to its reliability and validity, the FES has been used widely in research on issues relating to falls in older adults (Yardley et al., 2005). Previous researchers have demonstrated that the FES is useful when seeking to predict future falls and decline in ability to complete ADL (Cumming et al., 2000).

In previous studies, the ABC has been valid and scores have been reliable for assessing falls efficacy among active older adults. It consists of 16 questions rated on a scale of zero to 100 (Powell & Myers, 1995). The scores from each of the 16 items are averaged to provide an overall score that can range from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating better balance confidence when performing ADL, especially in regards to detecting loss of confidence in highly functioning older adults (Powell & Myers, 1995). Both the ABC and FES are based on Bandura’s (1997) theory of self-efficacy, which refers to general confidence in ability to complete a task which will result in a desired outcome.

One-repetition maximum (1-RM) testing was performed on a plate-loaded leg press machine (LGPRS). The 1-RM strength is defined as the maximum amount of weight successfully lifted for one repetition. Prior to 1-RM testing, each participant underwent two separate practice sessions in order to receive instructions for proper lifting and breathing techniques, and establish familiarity with the movement. To promote learning of the leg press machine and reduce potential muscle soreness following exertion (Martel et al., 2006; Tracy et al., 1999), participants were provided with practice opportunities prior to the day of testing. During each practice session, participants performed 10 repetitions of each exercise with little or no resistance to allow for familiarization with the equipment and testing routines. On the third visit, participants completed approximately 5 min of stationary cycling and stretching exercises, and then performed the 1-RM test. Progressively higher levels of resistance were administered until failure to successfully complete one repetition.

Table 2 lists pertinent summary statistics for the sample (n = 85), including demographics, frequency of moderate physical activity, and estimates of test–retest reliability for the data collected using the instruments described above. In the present study, the sample was composed of mainly female older adults, who were physically active. Additionally, statistically significant Pearson r measures of test–retest reliability were obtained using the FES (.80), ABC (.91), BBT (.91), and LGPRES (.97) scales.

fn.p: Note: BBT = Berg balance test; FES = Falls efficacy scale; ABC = Activities-specific balance confidence scale; LGPRS = 1-repitition maximum leg press.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: The FES and ABC were both used as separate predictors of falls efficacy. Given that fall frequency increases with age for both men and women (Stevens et al., 2006), the AGE variable was added as a third predictor. Because physiological deterioration is associated with longevity and is often a marker associated with unintended falls (Nazarko, 2006), lower body functioning was assessed using the BBT and LGPRS to make up the lower body function/variate (LBFUNCT).

The distribution of scores on all scales was examined, and the skewness and kurtosis statistics were within the acceptable range meeting the normality assumption of multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA; Tabachnick & Fidell, 2000). The first step in CCA involved a canonical correlation analysis which determined the correlation between the pair of composite variables (i.e., the FES/ABC/AGE function with LBFUNCT). Each individual participant score on the LBFUNCT was then computed. To compute these latent scores, the function coefficients for each dependent measure were multiplied by participants’ z-scores on the two criterion variables (i.e., BBT/LGPRS) and summed together to get product variate scores, which were saved under a unique name that represented the concurrent composition of each dependent variable within the variate (i.e., LBFUNCT). Once LBFUNCT z-scores were computed, simple and multiple regressions predicted these scores with all possible combinations of the predictor variable set. There were seven possible combinations using at least one of the three independent measures (i.e., FES, ABC, and AGE) to predict the LBFUNCT scores, which reflected latent multivariate measures (rc 2/Rc 2).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The canonical correlation analysis indicated a statistically significant effect for the overall multivariate model (Λ = .49, F(6, 160) = 11.46, p < .001), which provided sufficient evidence to continue with the CCA. Because there were two dependent variables in the criterion variable set, two sets of criterion variable composite scores were created for both canonical functions. It is important to note that, as expected across both canonical functions, the multiple regression coefficients (R 2) with all predictors entered, were equivalent to the Rc 2 coefficients, with the LBFUNCT I (.509) and II (.002) being the same in both the univariate and multivariate case. Furthermore, the effect size for function I (Rc 2 = .509 or 50.9%) was the only important criterion function/variate to examine. This statistically significant result indicated that over half of the variance in function I (i.e., LBFUNCT I) was explained by the predictor variable set (i.e., FES/ABC/AGE). It also reproduced the vast majority (over 99%) of maximum correlations between the variables within the predictor and criterion variable sets, while function II only reproduced less than 0.2% of the maximum correlations between each variable set. Thus, a CCA on function II was not warranted in this research situation.

For the predictor variable set, the standardized weights (with structure coefficients) for AGE, FES, ABC were .69 (.84), .20 (.57), –.43 (–.71), respectively. This provides evidence that AGE contributed more to the makeup of the predictor variate than either of the two measures of falls efficacy (i.e., FES, ABC). For the outcome variable set, the standardized weights (with structure coefficients) for BBT and LGPRS were –.84 (–.96) and –.29 (–.65), respectively. Thus, the BBT contributed more than LGPRS to LBFUNCT I. The unique and common components of variance explained on LBFUNCT I were then computed across the three predictors and is illustrated in Table 3 . Again, it is important to note that the Rc 2 effect size in the last line of Table 3, where all the predictor variables are entered, is equivalent to the Rc 2 effect size initially identified after the statistically significant effect primarily including LBFUNCT I (Rc 2 = .509 or 50.9%). In this full model case, the Rc 2 when all predictors are entered simultaneously always equals the squared canonical correlation because the two analyses are exactly the same. Table 3 presents the rc 2/Rc 2 effect sizes for each of the three predictors entered either alone or in concert with one another in all possible combinations. The rc 2/Rc 2 values are of interest and are converted into percentages that reflect the amount of the canonical variable (LBFUNCT) explained by each predictor(s) when entered into the model.

caption.p: Unique and Common Components of Predictive Ability Among Each Predictor Variable on LBFUNCT I

fn.p: Note: Dependent measure: LBFUNCT I; U = Unique; C = Common; FES = Falls efficacy scale; ABC = Activities-specific balance confidence scale; LBFUNCT I = Function I.

Canonical correlations: rc
2 (FES) = 16.8%a; rc
2(ABC) = 25.4%b; rc
2(AGE) = 35.7%c; Rc 2(FES, ABC) = 28.1%; Rc 2 (FES, AGE) = 44.2%; Rc 2 (ABC, AGE) = 49.6%; Rc 2 (AGE, FES, ABC) = 51%d.

sec.p: From Table 3, it can be surmised that the majority of the unique explained variance on the LBFUNCT I was predicted by AGE (22.9%), followed by the ABC measure of falls efficacy (6.8%), followed by the FES (1.4%). Notably, over 90% (i.e., 15.4%/16.8% = 91.7%) of the rc 2 attributable to variance in FES scores was commonly shared among the ABC and AGE variables, albeit mostly with the ABC measure of falls efficacy (7.1%/16.8% = 42.2%). This suggests one could quite reasonably drop FES from the predictive model without losing much predictive power, especially considering both measures assess the same construct.

Interestingly, the ABC predictor shared (see COMMON row) more of its predictive capacity on the LBFUNCT I than any of the three predictors. Almost three fourth (18.6%/25.4% = 73.2%) of the rc 2 attributable to variance in ABC scores was shared with AGE and FES or in combination with both AGE and FES. On the contrary, the AGE variable shared only approximately one third (12.8%/35.7% = 35.85%) of its total predictive ability on LBFUNCT I with the falls efficacy predictors (i.e., FES and ABC). Consequently, a majority of the predictive capability of AGE represented a unique partition of explained variance, distinguishing AGE as truly the most important single predictor.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: CCA showed balance confidence as measured by the ABC and age to be noteworthy predictors of balance; yet, age was determined to be more important than balance confidence when predicting balance and leg strength (i.e., balance functioning) simultaneously. Age uniquely explained more variance in balance and leg strength, and was a superior predictor to falls efficacy when predicting balance functioning among this physically active sample of older adults. Although results from one study showed fall rates to be similar between young–old and old–old elderly (Berg, Alessio, Mills, & Tong 1997), many previous studies have corroborated that the incidence of falls inexorably increases as the older adult ages even further (Sattin, 1992; Sattin et al., 1990; Tinetti & Speechly, 1989). Moreover, results from this study are consistent with literature supporting physical and motor deterioration detrimentally affecting balance ability among older adults (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2004; Stevens et al., 2006; Yannessa, 2008).

With regard to falls efficacy, the FES has been perhaps the most widely used instrument to measure the construct; however, research suggests that it is best suited to assess more frail groups of elderly (Kulmala et al., 2007; Yannessa et al., 2008). Results from this study, and others (e.g., Myers et al., 1996) involving moderate to high functioning older adults, suggest that the ABC does a better job predicting lower body functioning among active older adults. As compared to the FES, items on the ABC include questions related to more lifestyle activities such as stepping onto an escalator and being bumped while walking through a shopping mall. These activities are more representative of encounters commonly faced by mobile older adult populations. Because of this, the ABC stands as a viable alternative to consider when assessing falls efficacy among dynamic older adults, especially as compared to the traditional FES.

sec.title: Limitations to Commonality Analysis
sec.p: Both Pedhazur (1997) and Schneider (2008) caution against using commonality analysis for explanatory purposes and encourage its use as a predictive analysis. This is because they argue that the uniqueness in each predictor variable can contain some outcome variance not captured by other predictors in any given regression model. Along with the mathematically complex computations which arise when the number of predictor variables increase (Cooley & Lohnes, 1976; Seibold & McPhee, 1979), there is also an inability to statistically test commonalities, which has also been brought up as a potential limitation. However, this former restriction is not necessarily debilitating since result interpretations are made after a statistically significant Rc 2 has been detected. In the present example, a statistically significant and noteworthy Rc 2 effect size existed between the predictor and outcome variable sets, thus refuting the argument that null hypothesis statistical significance testing was necessary for testing commonalities. It should be noted, however, that the small sample size in the present study (n = 85) did limit the generalizability of findings from this study. Stevens (1986) recommends that at least 20 cases per variable should be in a sample for the first canonical correlation. If two canonical correlations are of interest, then 40–60 cases per variable should be in a sample size. In the current study, this endorsement could not be heeded, yet there was still sufficient power to detect a statistically significant squared canonical correlation complemented by a noteworthy effect size (Rc 2 = .51, p < .001).

sec.title: Usefulness of Commonality Analysis
sec.p: Commonality analysis can be a useful tool to precisely quantify, “how much explained variance is attributable uniquely to predictors, and in common across all combinations of the predictors … [thus] more fully conceptualizing and representing regression dynamics” (Zientek & Thompson, 2006, p. 306). Researchers in the health professions can conduct CCAs to better understand unique and common contributions of independent variables to predict outcome variable sets, while still holding fidelity to the relationships among variables and honoring the level of scale that data are collected (i.e., not reducing interval level predictor variable data to nominal groups) (Thompson, 1985). Capraro and Capraro (2001) state that by using commonality analysis, “the variance explained from the full model can be understood and the contributions of each separate variables can be interpreted in relation to the full model for the results of the unique effects … to determine the most parsimonious model and relevant data sources” (p. 22). Given that researchers in the health professions often attempt to explain “the most with the least” to yield a higher probability of replicating results, it is important to evaluate studies by interpreting model effects with knowledge of potential guidelines for the deletion of redundant predictors. In addition, the extension of a regression technique to the canonical case (Knapp, 1978) reinforces the recognition that canonical analysis is the most general case of parametric significance testing (Thompson, 1985).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: More recently, Nimon, Lewis, Kane, & Haynes (2008) published syntax to use with the statistical package R (R Development Core Team, 2007) which automates the calculations of unique and commonly explained variance. This development was noteworthy, as the computations for commonality analysis are not included in the most commonly used statistical software packages (Onwuegbuzie & Daniel, 2003). In addition, CCA may also not be widely used by program evaluators in public and allied health because the interpretive value of such analyses are not widely known by researchers (Nimon et al., 2008). This is unfortunate but certainly fathomable given the multitude of regression-based techniques available health program evaluators. Also, practitioners in the health sciences are often more inclined to assess binary outcomes (e.g., disease or no disease), count data (e.g., number of infections), and/or survival outcomes (e.g., dead or censored). Even still, as Mood suggested back in 1969, “perhaps commonality analysis should be considered more frequently in contemporary practice in … research” (p. 480). Perhaps now, more than 40 years later, the time has come to operationalize this alternative regression technique more frequently in evaluation studies within the health professions. Future research would benefit from using CCA to understand how various other psychological constructs (other than falls efficacy) predict fall-related outcomes in longitudinal studies of older adults.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) received no financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article.
